This supersedes IRM 7.11.12 dated September 14,
Tax Exempt and Government Entities Employee Plans
Table of Contents
Advice Requests
page (
) Purpose: This IRM gives the procedures for requesting technical advice for Employee Plans (EP) Determination Letter (DL) application and for requests for relief under IRC
) Audience: EP Determinations and Quality Assurance (QA) staff. (
) Policy Owner: Director, EP. (
) Program Owner: EP. (

) Program Goals: The goal of EP Determinations is to ensure that plans are compliance with the tax laws by reviewing applications for DLs, opinion and advisory letters, and to protect the public interest by applying the tax law with integrity and fairness to all. (

) The Office of Associate Chief Counsel (Employee Beneﬁts, Exempt tions and Employment Taxes) (Associate Office) in Washington, D.C: a. Reviews all technical advice requests. b. Is responsible for determining the resolution and guidance for the set of facts in the request. c. Issues a resolution in the form of written guidance called a Technical Advice Memorandum (TAM). (
) Technical advice requests help to: a. Resolve complex issues. b. Establish and maintain consistent holdings throughout the IRS. (

) Associate Office’s issuance of a TAM on the qualiﬁed status of a plan the requesting taxpayer from appealing within the IRS for issues addressed the TAM. The TAM is based on a speciﬁc set of facts for only the taxpayer receives the TAM and no other plan sponsor can rely on that TAM. (
) A request for technical advice can be initiated by EP Determinations or a taxpayer. The group manager decides whether to pursue technical advice. help, if necessary, from the EP QA Manager. (

) Submit your consideration for any technical advice to the EP QA Manager your group manager agrees. EP Quality Assurance (QA): a. Helps address the potential issues. b. Supports you in preparing the technical advice request. (
) The EP QA Manager with the agreement of the office of the Director, Employee Plans Rulings & Agreements must approve the request before mation is sent to TEGE Division Counsel (Division Counsel). (
) Division Counsel reviews the request for technical advice and must recommend that the request be submitted to Associate Office. (
) If Division Counsel denies the request for technical advice but the group manager still believes a request is warranted, follow the reconciliation proce- dures in Rev. Proc.
, section
If the group manager decides that request for technical advice from a taxpayer is unwarranted, the taxpayer appeal that decision using the steps in Rev. Proc.
, section
Internal Revenue Manual
Technical Advice Requests 7.11.12
The Office of Associate Chief Counsel (Employee Beneﬁts, Exempt Organiza- tions and Employment Taxes) (Associate Office) in Washington, D.C:

Associate Office’s issuance of a TAM on the qualiﬁed status of a plan prevents the requesting taxpayer from appealing within the IRS for issues addressed by the TAM. The TAM is based on a speciﬁc set of facts for only the taxpayer who receives the TAM and no other plan sponsor can rely on that TAM.
Submit your consideration for any technical advice to the EP QA Manager after your group manager agrees. EP Quality Assurance (QA):

If Division Counsel denies the request for technical advice but the group manager still believes a request is warranted, follow the reconciliation proce- dures in Rev. Proc. 2022-2, section 5.01. If the group manager decides that a request for technical advice from a taxpayer is unwarranted, the taxpayer may appeal that decision using the steps in Rev. Proc. 2022-2, section 5.03.
Employee Plans Determination Letter Program
These acronyms, terms and deﬁnitions are used in this IRM:

) Requests for relief from retroactive revocation or modiﬁcation of a determina- tion letter under IRC
) will be the decision of the Director, EP for Relief and Agreements (Director). IRC

) A request for relief can occur only when the plan has a determination letter and the specialist discovers the plan document contains faulty language or fails to include required language. In other words, the determination letter was issued in error.

ity is based on when the language was effective. The request can be initiated by the taxpayer or specialist assigned to the If initiated by the taxpayer, it must be submitted to specialist assigned to case prior to the issuance of the ﬁnal adverse determination letter. If initiated by the taxpayer, the request for retroactive relief must be in The request must contain content speciﬁed in Rev. Proc.
, section (updated annually). The taxpayer’s written request for relief must: a. State that relief is being made under IRC

(b). b. State the relief sought. c. Explain the reasons and arguments in support of the relief sought; d. Include any documents bearing on the request. The specialist will submit the request and accompanying information to the group manager who will make the decision to accept or deny the request relief. a. If the group manager believes that the request should be denied or further consideration is warranted to make an appropriate tion, the request will be sent to Division Counsel based on geography subject matter. b. Division Counsel will review the information from the group and memorandum to the group manager as to whether the determination letter should be “applied without retroactive effect” under IRC The group manager will decide whether IRC
(b) relief should be after consideration of the legal advice of Division Counsel if requested and advise the specialist to prepare and transmit a recommendation to the Director. See Exhibit
, Recommendation Memorandum for IRC
(b) Relief for a sample recommendation memorandum.

a. If the group manager believes that the request should be denied or further consideration is warranted to make an appropriate recommenda- tion, the request will be sent to Division Counsel based on geography or subject matter. b. Division Counsel will review the information from the group and furnish a memorandum to the group manager as to whether the determination letter should be “applied without retroactive effect” under IRC
Note: See Exhibit 7.11.12-2, Recommendation Memorandum for IRC 7805(b) Relief for a sample recommendation memorandum.

The Director will evaluate the recommendation memorandum and if necessary, consult with the appropriate Division Counsel office, to determine if relief will be granted and will return a signed memorandum back to the group. The memorandum will either indicate “limited” or “not limited” retroactivity.
The memorandum will either indicate “limited” or “not limited” retroactivity.

) Request technical advice: a. For assistance on any technical or procedural question that develops during any proceeding before the Internal Revenue Service (Service) when the application of the law to the facts involved is unclear. b. When the question involves the interpretation and proper application any legal authority, including legislation, court decisions, regulations, notices, revenue rulings, revenue procedures, to a speciﬁc set of that concerns the treatment of an item in a tax period or under tion. (
) The group manager must concur (and the case ﬁle documented) that a technical advice request is: a. Warranted based on the facts of the case or b. Mandatory. (

) A TAM may not be requested for prospective or hypothetical transactions except for certain TAMs in connection with a taxpayer’s request for a nation letter on a matter within the jurisdiction of the Commissioner, TE/GE pursuant to Rev. Proc.

) A request for a TAM is mandatory regarding qualiﬁed retirement plan concerning plans for which the Service is proposing to issue a revocation because of certain ﬁduciary actions that violate the exclusive beneﬁt rule of IRC
(a) and are subject to Part
of Subtitle B of Title
of the Retirement Income Security Act of

) Technical advice can’t be requested until all other case issues have been resolved. Before you request technical advice and during the technical process, keep the taxpayer informed and give them an opportunity to pate in the process.

) Technical advice can’t be requested until all other case issues have been resolved. Before you request technical advice and during the technical process, keep the taxpayer informed and give them an opportunity to partici- pate in the process. (
) While a case is under the jurisdiction of the Director, a taxpayer may make oral or written request that the group manager refer an issue to the Office for technical advice.

Technical advice can’t be requested until all other case issues have been resolved. Before you request technical advice and during the technical advice process, keep the taxpayer informed and give them an opportunity to partici
pate in the process.
) If the group manager decides that the taxpayer’s request is unwarranted, group manager will notify the taxpayer. (
) A taxpayer’s request for technical advice will not be denied merely because Associate Office has already provided legal advice, other than a TAM, to ﬁeld office on the matter. (
) The taxpayer may appeal the group manager’s denial of the request for referral by submitting to the group manager, within

calendar days after ﬁcation that the request was denied, a written statement of the reasons why the matter should be referred to the Associate Office, in accordance with procedures set out in Rev. Proc.
, Section

) The Director will determine whether the issue should be referred for advice on the basis of the statements of the ﬁeld office and the taxpayer. conference will be held with the taxpayer or the taxpayer’s representative. (

) If the Director determines that a TAM is not warranted, the taxpayer will be informed in writing of the proposed denial of the request and the reasons the denial (unless doing so would prejudice the Government’s interest). (
) The decision of the Director may be reviewed but not appealed. (
) A pre-submission conference is required under Rev. Proc.
, Section
before a formal request for technical advice is sent to the Associate Office. (

) Pre-submission conferences are mandatory because they promote processing of requests for technical advice. A pre-submission conference the ﬁeld office, ﬁeld counsel, taxpayer, and the Associate Office agree on a. Appropriate scope of the technical advice request. b. Factual information and documents that must be included in formal mission of the request for technical advice. Note: A pre-submission conference isn’t an alternate procedure for evaluating merits of the positions presented. The conference is intended only to
Note: A pre-submission conference isn’t an alternate procedure for evaluating the merits of the positions presented. The conference is intended only to facili-

) Prior to requesting a pre-submission conference, the ﬁeld office and must exchange proposed statements of the pertinent facts and issues, to include any facts in dispute, issues the parties intend to discuss, any legal analysis and supporting authorities, and any background information that parties believe would facilitate the Associate Office’s understanding of the issues to be discussed. (
) If the taxpayer fails to provide a statement of pertinent issues and facts a reasonable time, the conference may be scheduled without the taxpayer’s statements. (
) The QA reviewer and the Division Counsel attorney coordinate the of the conference, based on the time frames provided by the Associate (
) No taping, stenographic or other type of verbatim recording of the may be done by any party.
The QA reviewer and the Division Counsel attorney coordinate the scheduling of the conference, based on the time frames provided by the Associate Office.

During the pre-submission conference, the Associate Office may raise new issues in addition to those submitted by the ﬁeld office and the taxpayer.

EP R&A Technical Advisor Prepare a draft proposed Statement of Issues and Facts (Draft Statement) import into the Nondisclosable folder and name it “Tech Advice - Draft Statement”. The Draft Statement includes these sections: a. Issues - speciﬁc questions or issues for the Associate Office to address. b. Facts - a synopsis of the relevant background or plan history and the speciﬁc plan provisions in dispute. Include any information that would help the Associate Office understand the issues to be discussed during the conference. c. Law - legal analysis including relevant statutory provisions, regulations, revenue rulings, revenue procedures, notices, or any other authority. d. Plan Sponsor’s Position - arguments presented by the plan sponsor (if available). e. IRS’s Position - analysis and arguments in support of the IRS’s position. Coordinate with your group manager to get QA’s help in forming the position. Provide any relevant legal authority contrary to our position or state that there isn’t any. See Exhibit

, Sample Statement of Issues and Facts, for an Once the Draft Statement is ready, email the statement to your group for approval. The email from the group manager granting approval should be imported and made a part of the work papers. Send a copy of the Draft Statement to the plan sponsor for their review and comments. Prepare a cover letter which states that comments are welcome but not required and that the draft is subject to change. If the plan sponsor disagrees with the Draft Statement, they should submit a statement, in the same format, detailing their position and a cover letter ex- plaining the issues in dispute. They should provide any relevant legal contrary to their position or state that there isn’t any. The plan sponsor’s statement should be copied into the Nondisclosable Folder and labeled “Tech Advice - Plan Sponsor Draft Statement”.

[Section 23 of Rev. Proc. 2022-4, 2022-X I.R.B. XXX] [Section 12 of Rev. Proc. 2022-5, 2022-X I.R.B. XXX], sets forth criteria which must be met for an organization to obtain relief under § 7805(b). First, ***

Delegation Order 30-1 (Rev. 3) delegates authority to the Director, [EO] [EP] [Rulings and Agreements] [Examinations], to prescribe the extent to which any ruling relating to the internal revenue laws shall be applied without retroactive effect for letter rulings and determination letters issued by the Commissioner, Tax Exempt and Government Entities.
In the present case, [insert analysis taking into account relevant criteria]

We believe granting relief under § 7805(b) [would] [would not] be appropriate in this case. [Taxpayer name] [has] [has not] met the criteria of Rev. Proc. [2022-4] [ 2022-5] for relief under § 7805(b) because [summarize reasons for recommendation].

Therefore, we recommend the Director, [EO] [EP] [Rulings and Agreements] [Examinations] exercise discretionary authority [to limit] [not to limit] the retroactivity of the revocation. In accordance with [section 23 of Rev. Proc. 2022-4] [section 12 of Rev. Proc. 2022-5], revocation of [Taxpayer’s] exempt status should be effective [Date] based on [signiﬁcance of date].
[If decision is not to limit retroactivity, Director’s office to provide rationale for decision if not otherwise described previously in memorandum.]
7.11 Employee Plans Determination Letter
Exhibit 7.11.12-3 (01-08-2018) Sample Statement of Issues and Facts
INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE STATEMENT OF ISSUES AND FACTS Taxpayer’s Name: Taxpayer Address: Taxpayer Identiﬁcation No. Years Involved: Date of Conference: or (No Conference Held)
Issue(s):
Sample language: Whether the Plan meets the minimum participation requirements of section 401(a)(26) of the Internal Revenue Code (the “Code”)?

Sample language: Whether the Plan is required to include a reference to section 457 of the Internal Revenue Code (the “Code”) in its deﬁnition of compensation for purposes of applying the limits of section 415 of the Code?
Facts:

Provide a synopsis of the relevant background or history of the plan and the speciﬁc plan provisions in question to help the Associate Office understand the issues. The essential facts should be fully represented. Use short quotations from documents in the case to aid in identifying particular areas when the conclusion depends on the interpretation of such language. However, avoid lengthy quotations whenever practicable.

Sample language: xxxxxx (hereafter “Taxpayer”), Employer Identiﬁcation Number of (enter number), adopted xxxx (the Plan) on (enter date). The Plan was originally effective (enter date). The Plan year ends on (enter date). (Choice: The Plan last received a favorable determination letter from the Internal Revenue Service on (enter date). OR The Plan has never received a favorable determination letter.) Section 2.3 provides the deﬁnition of Compensation for purposes of section 415 of the Code is...
Law:

Refer to any relevant statutory provisions, regulations, revenue ruling, revenue procedures, notices, tax treaties, court decisions, or any other application authority. Ensure that all citations are directly on point. Use short quo- tations directly from the law when necessary but avoid lengthy quotations whenever practicable.
Sample language: Revenue Ruling 76-259, 1976-2 CB 111, provides that the pension beneﬁt may be offset only by the vested portion of the proﬁt sharing plan account balance.

Sample language: Section 1.401-1(b)(1)(i) of the Income Tax Regulations (“Regulations”) deﬁnes a qualiﬁed pension plan as a plan established and maintained by an employer to provide deﬁnitely determinable beneﬁts to its employees.
Exhibit 7.11.12-3 (Cont. 1) (01-08-2018) Sample Statement of Issues and Facts
Taxpayer’s Position:
arguments presented by the plan sponsor and their POA. Skip section if none available. This section is if the plan sponsor requested the technical advice.
Service’s Position:
Include analysis and arguments in support of the IRS’s position. Make a reasonable, good faith effort to fully prepare this section but coordinate with your group manager and QA when necessary.
